title: 114_s1454
content: The "Transportation and Logistics Hiring Reform Act" is the short title of this legislation. It includes definitions for various terms used in the Act. The Act defines an "entity" as a person involved in shipping, brokerage, freight forwarding, household goods transportation, air or ocean freight services, or customs brokerage. The Act defines an "entity" as a person involved in shipping, brokerage, freight forwarding, household goods transportation, air or ocean freight services, or customs brokerage. Section 111.2 of title 19, Code of Federal Regulations, outlines definitions for various entities including motor carriers subject to federal regulations and warehouses as defined in the Uniform Commercial Code. The term "motor carrier" refers to carriers subject to federal financial responsibility and safety regulations. The term "State" encompasses all 50 states, political subdivisions, intrastate agencies, and other political agencies across different regions. The Act defines an "entity" as a person involved in shipping, brokerage, freight forwarding, household goods transportation, air or ocean freight services, or customs brokerage in the Northern Mariana Islands, the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico, Guam, and the Virgin Islands. National hiring standards for motor carriers are established. National hiring standards for motor carriers are established. Before tendering a shipment, an entity must verify that the hired motor carrier is registered, has the required insurance coverage, and does not have an unsatisfactory safety fitness rating. The Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration issues ratings equivalent to unsatisfactory fitness ratings. Compliance with these ratings is the only evidence admissible in civil actions for negligent selection or retention of a motor carrier. Other data maintained by the Administration cannot be used as evidence in such cases. The Secretary of Transportation must establish safety fitness determination regulations for motor carriers within 18 months of the enactment of the Act. Motor carriers must comply with all applicable Federal safety laws. SEC. 4. APPLICABILITY AND EFFECTIVE DATE. This Act applies to actions started after its enactment, regardless of when the harm or conduct occurred.
